Daniel y sus demás compañeros han conformado este banco comunal denominado Alto Yapaz, donde él ha sido nombrado tesorero, prometió cumplir con sus responsabilidades delegadas e hizo compromisos de pagar puntualmente a MFP, del cual está agradecido por el crédito facilitado. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes, para que abone a su chacra de café, y de ese modo trate de adelantar la producción, considera que la cantidad requerida le será suficiente.
texts.en:
Daniel is 64 years old and has been married 45 years. He is the father of 6 children and currently lives in his house with his wife and grandson. He is a farmer with a lot of experience. Together with his wife, they have worked many agricultural jobs. Through this work, they accumulated guts and experience, learning which months are good for cultivating and fertilizing. Since then they've arrived at the conclusion that growing pineapple is very difficult, while growing bananas is easier. However what is really profitable, though also labor-intensive, is the cultivation of coffee. Daniel planted this product non-stop throughout the entire year, investing a lot, but also gaining a lot. This made him feel very proud to be a farmer. Now he is very happy because the coffee farm he planted last year is already about to bear fruit. For that reason he wants to complete fertilization of the coffee plants, so that they will be harvested on time and so that in this way he can have an alternate production and will have money to cover his family's expenses. Daniel and the rest of his coworkers have formed a communal bank called Alto Yapaz, where he has been named treasurer. He has promised to fulfill his responsibilities as an officer. He also made a commitment to pay on time to MFP, to which he is grateful for providing this loan. He is requesting this money to buy fertilizers in order to fertilize his coffee crop, and in this way try to improve production. He expects that the requested amount will be sufficient.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Morey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer for coffee plants

loans.name: Mariluz

texts.es: Mariluz tiene 34 años, hace 6 meses se separó de su pareja, es madre de dos hijos, actualmente vive en su casa propia. Se dedica a la agricultura y también prepara el almuerzo para todos los peones que realizaban la faena de sus cultivos. Desde muy niña aprendió a limpiar sus chacras sacando las malezas (hierbas) con el machete. Ahora prefirió comprar funguicidas para evitar la continuidad de las hierbas que acechan sus plantas, desde entonces ya no realiza con la misma frecuencia el macheteo; pero después de haber esparcido este herbecida cree que la producción de sus platanales ha aminorado, y las hojas se están tornando amarillas por lo que está preocupada y está buscando una solución inmediata para recuperar la producción de sus plátanos. Pero al margen de todas sus dificultades, dice estar muy contenta con sus cultivos y piensa incrementar su producción para tener cosechas alternadas. Mariluz está muy contenta por integrar este banco comunal, y se ha ofrecido en apoyar en las labores de secretaria, del mismo modo se compromete en hacer sus pagos de forma muy puntual. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes para que pueda abonar sus chacras de plátanos, y de ese modo mejorar la producción de sus plantas.
texts.en:
Mariluz is 34 years old. Six months ago she separated from her husband. She is the mother of two children. She currently lives in her own house. She works in agriculture and also prepares lunch for the laborers that cultivate her farm. Since she was a little girl, she learned to weed her farm using a machete. Recently, she bought herbicides in order to kill the weeds that threaten her plants. Since then, she hasn’t use the machete as much, but after having applied the herbicide, she believes that the production of her banana plants has slowed, and the leaves are turning yellow. She is worried about this and is looking for an immediate solution to restore the production of her bananas. Despite all her difficulties, she is very happy with her farm and is considering increasing her productions so that she can grow alternate crops. Mariluz is very happy to be a part of this community bank. She has offered to help as a secretary, and also pledges to make her payments on time. The money that she requests is in order for her to buy fertilizers so that she can maintain her plots of bananas and, in this way, improve the production of her plants.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her plants

loans.name: Nueva Jerusalem Group

texts.es:
el grupo nueva jerusalem este integrado de la siguiente forma:
la Sra. Felipa M. tiene 51 años de edad, es soltera, tiene dos hijas las cuales estan estudiando en el instituto Tecnico Sierra de Nacaome. ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas y quesillo, ella tiene su negocio hace 4 años, vive en el barrio Maria Auxiliadora, cuando las hijas tienen ratos libres le ayudan a producir las tortillas y tambien a venderlas ya que se desplazan a vender las tortillas en la comunidad que viven. el sueño de la Sra. M. es graduar a sus dos hijas de la Universidad.
La joven Dixcy P.  tiene dos años de tener su pulperia ya que le gusta bastante las ventas fue que ella decidio poner este negocio tambien vende golosinas, ella le ayuda a su madre economicamente su sueño es estudiar en la universidad y poder poner un supermercado.
La Sra. Rosa Amelia V. tiene 34 años de edad, vive en union libre con su compañero de hogar tienen dos hijos los cuales estan estudiando en la escuela comunal.
ella vende leña y ropa desde hace 10 años y tiene bastantes clientes su mayor sueño es que sus hijos sean unos profesionales.
texts.en:
The Nueva Jerusalem Group is made up of the following people:

Ms. Felipa M. is 51 years old. She is single and has two children who are studying at the Technical Institute of the Mountans of Nacome. She sells tortillas and quesillo, a soft creamy cheese. She has had her business for four years. She lives in the Maria Auxiliadora neighborhood. When her children have free time, they help her to make and sell the tortillas, since they moved to their neighborhood to sell tortillas. Ms. M.’s dream is that her children will graduate from college.

Dixcy P. is a young woman and has had a small grocery store for two years. She really enjoys being in sales and decided to also sell candies. Ms. P. helps her mother with her expenses. Her dream is to study in a university and to own a supermarket.

Ms. Rosa Amelia V. is 34 years old. She is in a common-law marriage and has two children who are studying in school. She has sold firewood and clothes for 10 years and has many customers. Her biggest dream is that her children will be professionals.


Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cheese, firewood, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, bread, coffee, shirts, pants, shorts, underwear, boxers, brassieres.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Reina Margarita

texts.es:
la sra, Reina C. tiene 30 años de dad, es vecina de la colonia Fraternidad y esta casada, tiene dos hijos, uno de ellos esta en el colegio y la otra en la escuela, su esposo trabaja en la albañileria y se ayudan economicamente para sacar adelante su hogar.
se decica al negoci ohace 6 años, tiene muchos clientes, es muy esforzada y dinamica.
para la venta de tortillas necesita comprar maiz, leña, cal, agua.
es por tal razon que necesita el credito ya que desea comprar maiz para almacenarlo porque en los meses siguientes se pone mas caro.
su mayor anelo es crecer y estudiar y a sus dos hijos hacerlos profesionales para que en el futuro puedan tener mejor oportunidad en esta vida.
texts.en:
Mrs. Reina C. is 30 years old and lives in the Fraternidad neighborhood. She is married and has two children. Her son is in high school and her daughter is in also in school. Her husband works as a bricklayer and they help economically to keep the home going.

She has been working in the business for 6 years and has many clients. She is forceful and dynamic. To sell tortillas, she needs to buy corn, firewood, lime, and water. For this reason she needs a loan. She also wants to buy corn to store because in the upcoming months it will become more expensive.

Her greatest wish is to grow and study and that her two children will become professionals so that in the future they will have more opportunities in life.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Morey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy firewood, salt, lime, and cornmeal

loans.name: Maria Suyapa

texts.es:
la Sra. Maria C. tiene 42 años de edad y se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, ella es dueña de su propia pulperia que posee desde hace 15 años, es un bonito negocio que ha podido obtener gracias a la ayuda de Dios y de su gran esfuerzo, ella tambien vende zapatos.
tiene un hijo de 15 años de edad que esta estudiando en el colegio de San Lorenzo, el es su adoracion.
necesita el prestamo para poder aumentar su negocio y tener mas variedad de productos para ofrecer a sus clientes.
el sueño de ella es poder graduar a su hijo de la universidad para que tenga un mejor futuro y muchas oportinidades.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria C. is 42 years old, and sells popular consumer goods. She's the owner of her own convenience store that she's had for 15 years. It's a beautiful business that has been able to profit thanks to God and her great effort; she also sells shoes.

She has a fifteen-year-old son who's studying in the San Lorenzo school. He is her pride and joy. She needs a loan to help grow her business and to have a greater variety of products to offer her customers. Her dream is to be able to graduate her son from college so that he can have a better future with many opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Todd Schmid, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of churros, beverages, rice, beans, sugar, coffee, cookies, shampoos, deodorant, soups, candy, juices, toilet paper

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.es:
la Sra R. es madre soltera tiene 56 años de edad, tiene 4 hijos todos mayores de edad y se dedica a este tipo de actividad desde hace 8 años, ella vive en la colonia la fraternidad y ha podido salir adelante a pesar de los obstaculos que le ha dado la vida.
el negocio de las tortillas es muy rentable ya que porduce tortillas para varios clientes y con las utilidades a podido pagar su casa y lograr graduar a su ultimo hijo.
para la venta de las tortillas necesita comprar maiz, leña, cal, agua por esa razon necesita el credito.
ella piensa que en un futuro su vida va a cambiar y pueda mejorar su condicion de vida. su sueño es tener una fabrica de tortillas en la cual pueda tener muchas empleadas y asi contribuir con otras familias a salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. R. is a single mother, 56 years old, with 4 grown children. She has had this business for 8 years. She lives in La Fraternidad neighborhood and has been able to be successful in spite of life’s obstacles. Her tortilla business is very profitable and she produces tortillas for various clients and with the earnings she has been able to pay for her home and see her youngest child graduate. In order to sell tortillas she needs to buy corn, wood, lime, and water so she needs a loan. She believes in the future her life is going to change and she can improve her quality of life. She dreams of having a tortilla factory where she can have many employees and in this way help other families be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, wood, lime, and water

loans.name: Marcial

texts.es: Marcial tiene 34 años de edad, vive con su pareja hace 11 años, es padre de 3 hijos y actualmente viven en su casa propia. Los padres de Marcial  son personas dedicadas al cultivo de todo tipo de frutas, y él desde pequeño apoyaba a su padre en lo que le encomendara. A los 15 años sintió inclinación por la carpintería, por ello que buscó trabajar con personas con este oficio; empezó pasando maderas, cepillando retazos y finalmente, de a pocos, empezó con el lijado. Desde entonces decidió  independizarse, cultivaba sus propios productos y con las ganancias invertía en máquinas y herramientas de carpintería. Hasta que hace dos meses viene trabajando en este oficio, pero aun no le es muy rentable porque le lleva mucho tiempo la fabricación de un mueble porque todavía no cuenta con todas las herramientas necesarias, por ello que también trabaja como chofer, y no descuida sus cultivos, donde su esposa es su mayor apoyo, de esas tres maneras puede solventar los gastos de su familia. Pese a que recién se inicia en la carpintería, Marcial está muy contento con este trabajo, porque dice tener imaginación y creatividad para la fabricación de cada mueble. Ahora desea comprar mercadería para abrir una bodega que sea atendida por su esposa y así contar con un ingreso económico adicional. Marcial es un nuevo cliente de MFP, por lo que hace compromisos de cumplir con sus pagos de acuerdo al cronograma establecido por su asesor de crédito, también tiene muchas expectativas  del buen funcionamiento de su banco comunal. El dinero que solicita lo derivará en dos partes: una mínima para la compra de lijas y clavos de diversas pulgadas para su trabajo de carpintería; y la otra cantidad para la compra de mercadería para hacer realidad su sueño de contar con una bodega en su casa.
texts.en:
Marcial is 34 years old and has been living with his partner for 11 years. He is the father of 3 boys and now they live in their own house. Marcial's parents grow all types of fruit and ever since Marcial was little he has helped his father out where he can. When he was 15 he became interested in carpentry so he looked for work with people who worked in this profession. He began by passing wood, brushing pieces and finally, little by little, he began sandpapering. Since then he has decided to become independent, growing his own products and investing the profits in machines and tools for his carpentry. He has been working in this way for two months but it is still not very profitable because he still does not have all of the tools he needs so it takes a lot of time to make furniture. For this reason he also works as a driver and cares for his crops, where his wife is his greatest support. With these three businesses he is able to support his family. Despite being new to carpentry, Marcial is very happy in this job because he says making each piece of furniture takes imagination and creativity. Now he would like to buy merchandise to be able to open a warehouse that his wife would take care of and which would mean an additional income.

Marcial is a new client of MFP, which is why he is committed to meeting his payments in agreement with the timetable established by his credit assessor. He also has high expectations that his communal bank will work well. The money he is asking for will be divided into two parts: a certain amount will be used to buy sandpaper and nails of a variety of sizes for his carpentry work, the rest will buy merchandise to turn his dream of a warehouse in his house into a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials and merchandise for his warehouse

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es: Marcelino tiene 52 años, está separado hace 2 años, padre de 4 hijos y actualmente vive solo en su casa. Desde muy niño tuvo la predisposición por el cultivo de la tierra, virtud que heredó de su padre, a quien le gustaba tener la chacra limpia de yerbas y remover la tierra constantemente para que las plantas apresuren su producción. Cuando Marcelino formó su propia familia se propuso sembrar grandes hectáreas de diversos plantas (plátano, piña y café), en todo este tiempo en la fruta que mayor tiempo invierte es en la piña, cada 2 a 3 meses se tiene que remover la tierra y del mismo modo abonarla, eso le genera mayor inversión de tiempo y dinero; por ello ha decidido ya no sembrar piña, y quedarse solo con los plántanos y el café. Este año va a renovar sus plantas, para ello está preparando una hectárea de chacra. Marcelino está muy feliz con sus labores agrícolas, para él la agricultura es un arte, por ello hay que dedicarle el tiempo necesario, sólo así podrá ser muy rentable. La dificultad que se le presenta, generalmente, es la falta de dinero para invertir en sus cultivos tanto como el quisiera. Marcelino es un nuevo cliente de MFP, sus vecinos y amistades tiene un buen concepto de su persona, por ello que le nombraron fiscal de su banco comunal, este su primer préstamo, y hace compromisos de hacer efectivos sus pagos en las fechas señaladas. El dinero que solicita es para la comprar 3 bolsas de fertilizantes, como el nitrato y potasio, que le servirán para el abonado correspondiente de su chacra de plátanos.
texts.en:
Marcelino is 52 years old. He's been separated for two years, and is the father of four kids. He currently lives on his own at home. Since he was just a small boy, he had a predisposition for farming, a virtue he inherited from his father, who liked to have his small farm clear of weeds and to constantly turn the soil to speed up the growth of his plants. When Marcelino began his own family he decided to grow large acres (hectares) of diverse plants (bananas, pineapples, and coffee). With the pineapple, in which he's invested the greatest amount of time, every 2 to 3 months he has to turn the soil while fertilizing it at the same time. That takes him a larger investment of time and money; for that reason, he's decided to stop growing pineapples, and to work with just bananas and coffee. This year he's going to renovate his plants, so he's preparing a hectare of farmland. Marcelino is very happy with agricultural work; for him, agriculture is an art, so he must put in the necessary time. Only in that way will it become very profitable. The difficulty he confronts, generally, is the lack of money to invest in his farming as much as he would like.

Marcelino is a new client of MFP. His neighbors and friends place good trust in his character, so they named him financial leader of their communal bank, this being his first loan, and he agrees to ensure that payments are made on the indicated dates. The money he's requesting is intended to buy three bags of fertilizers, like nitrate and potassium, which will help him with the fertilization for his banana farm.


Translated from Spanish by Todd Schmid, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers for his banana farm

loans.name: Natividad

texts.es:
el Sr. Natividad tiene 42 años de edad se dedica al comercio, tiene tres hijos una mujer y dos varones, su esposa es maestra y trabaja en la escuela Estados Unidos de esta localidad, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitacion asi no descuida a sus hijos.
el negocio tiene un año de estar funcionando y le ha dejado muy buenas utilidades el solicita el prestamo para poder surtir mas su negocio ya que el dice que por la crisis economica desea comprar producto para terlo guardado ya que todo va a subir de precio en unos meses. su meta es poder ampliar su negocio y tener su propia bodega. a el le gustan mucho las frutas.
texts.en:
Natividad is a 42-year-old businessman and has three children: one daughter and two sons. His wife teaches at the Estados Unidos school in town. He sets up shop in his home so that he can also take care of his children. His business has been up and running for one year and has been very profitable for him. He's asking for a loan in order to better supply his store. Due to the economic crisis, he wants to buy and stock up on products before prices rise in the next few months. His goal is to expand his business and have his own small grocery store. He also loves fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, beans, rice, sugar, coffee, churros, sweets, toilet paper, chili peppers, milk, cookies, jelly, lard, oil, margarine

loans.name: Eduardo Jose

texts.es: Eduardo Z. se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de muebles de madera por mas de 16 años, el esta casado y es padre de 4 hijos, la hija mayor cursa la secundaria y los tres menores cursan la primaria, con los ingresos que el negocio le genera le permiten cubrir con los gastos del hogar, atraves de este negocio logro comprar su casa en la cual vive el y su familia, el comenzo a trabajar a los 14 años y a los 21 monto su propio taller de carpinteria con los ahorros que el tenia compro la maquinaria, los clientes que eran donde el trabajaba se pasaron a ser clientes de su negocio ya que el es muy bueno en su actividad, el tiene dos empleados en la acutualidad que le ayudan a fabricar sus muebles, sus clientes han crecido mucho en vista de las necesidades de ellos esta solicitando un credito para poder comprar mas madera y asi poder cumplir con todas las exigencias de todos ellos.
texts.en:
Eduardo Z. has been making and selling wooden furniture for more than 16 years. He is married with four children; his eldest daughter is in secondary school and his three youngest are in primary school. Through his business, he was able to buy the house in which he and his family live. The business now generates enough income to cover his household expenses. He started working at 14, and by 21 he used his savings to buy machinery and set up his own carpentry shop. The customers from his old work followed him to his new business since he is very good at his trade. He currently has two employees who help him manufacture the furniture. Seeing that his customer base has grown, he is asking for a loan to purchase more wood to meet all their needs.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cedar, mahogany, laurel and pine wood

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Las Vecinitas Group

texts.es:
el grupo las Vecinitas residen en la colonia 28 de marzo de a ciudad capital, consta de 3 mujeres muy luchadoras. las cuales se detallan a continuacion:
Fermina V. tiene 39 años de edad tiene un hijo y se dedica a la venta de naranjas, mangos, repollo, cebolla entre otros actividad que le genera muy buenos ingresos pero necesita comprar un local ambulante para poder mejorar la antencion de sus clientes.
Blanca B. de 55 años de edad es madre soltera con  3 hijos todos ellos son profesionales, ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas, desde muy joven empezo a trabajar ya que solo se dedico a trabajar y nunca pudo estudiar porque tenia que ayudarle a su madre a salir adelante con su hogar,
Yarleny G. vivi en union libre, ella tiene 33 años de edad y tiene 3 hijos, ella solo estudio la primaria ya que para su padre no era importante el estudiar sino que ganarse la vida trabajando, ella vende tortillas desde hace mas de 25 años.
todas ellas necesitan este credito para poder hacer crecer sus negocios y darle mejor vida a sus familias.
texts.en:
The Las Vecinitas group lives in the 28 de marzo neigbourhood in the capital city. The group consists of three women with fighting spirits as follows: Fermina V. is 39-years-old and has one son. She sells oranges, mangos, cabbages, onions and other produce. This brings in good income but she needs to buy a produce stand in order to improve her customer service. Blanca B. is 55-years-old and a single mother with three adult working children. She sells tortillas. She started working at a very young age and was never able to study because she had to help her mother keep the household running. Yarleny G. lives with her common-law husband, is 33-years-old and has 3 children. She only went as far as primary school because her father thought making a living by working was more important than studying. She has been selling tortillas for over 25 years. All three women need this loan in order to make their businesses grow and to improve the lives of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, water, corn flour, lime, fruits and vegetables

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fani Yamileth

texts.es: la Sra Fani G. compra y vende ropa para todo tipo de personas, asi mismo vende cosmeticos varios para dama, su producto lo distribuye en diferentes colonias cercanas a su casa de habitacion, con su negocio ella puede sostener a su hija, ella necesita un credito para poder comprar mas mercaderia ya que este dificil la situacion y necesita tener mas ganancias para poder sostener su hogar ya que en estos momentos esta pasando por una situacion bien dificil. ella cree que comprando mas mercaderia va a tener mayores ventas y asi poder darle aliementacion y educacion a su hija.
texts.en:
Fani G. buys and sells clothing for all types of people and also sells various women’s cosmetics. She sells her products in different neighbourhoods close to her home and this business allows her to support her daughter. She needs a loan so that she can purchase more merchandise. She is currently going through a very difficult situation, so she needs to earn more in order to support her household. She believes that by buying more merchandise, her sales will improve and she will be able to feed and educate her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's, women's and men's clothing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: el Sr. Pedro V. es una persona que se dedica a la compra de chatarra de hierro y piezas de vehiculos viejos que han sido chocados, estos los compra por libra y asi mismo los vende para ser reciclados y fabricar otros articulos, el es una persona muy responsable, trabajador, el tiene su proipio vehiculo para el acarreo del material y quiere el credito para poder comprar mas chatarra, el lleva su producto de la ciudad de tegucigalpa para la ciudad de danli y gracias a su negocio puede mantener su familia.
texts.en:
Pedro V. buys scrap metal and parts from old vehicles that have been demolished by the pound and sells them to be recycled or made in to other products. He is very responsible and works hard. He owns his own vehicle to transport the materials from Tegucigalpa to Danli. He would like a loan in order to purchase more scrap metal. Thanks to his business he is able to take care of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Deborah Delzell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy scrap metal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ela Rosa

texts.es: Ela Rosa A. se dedica a la produccion y venta de tortillas este es su principal negocio el cual le genera ingresos para sustentar su familia, las tortillas las vende en su colonia a diferentes mercaditos, pulperias y casas, ella tiene muy buena demanda, cuando ella deja de vender sus tortillas vende su otro producto que es ropa para cama , vajillas, toallas, esta actividad la hace por las tardes ya que las ventas de tortillas es de muy de mañana. con estos dos negocios ella saca el dinero para poder mantener su familia, ella solicita este prestamo para poder comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener mejores ventas.
texts.en:
Ela Rosa A.’s primary business is making and selling tortillas, which provides income to support her family. She sells the tortillas in her village at various small markets, grocery stores and homes. She has substantial demand for her tortillas. When she is not selling tortillas, she sells bedding, dishes, and towels. Tortillas are sold in the early morning and the other products are sold in the afternoon. With these two businesses, she makes money, which allows her to support her family. She is asking for the loan in order to buy supplies and merchandise that will improve sales.

Translated from Spanish by Deborah Delzell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy cornmeal, slaked lime (calcium hydroxide), salt, water, bedding, and dishes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es: Roberto tiene 38 años, es soltero, actualmente vive solo en su casa propia. Los trabajos agrícolas fueron y son parte de su vida, de carácter muy noble, siempre tiene la disposición de satisfacer las necesidades de sus hermanos y de los peones que trabajan para él en su afán de dar continuidad de las buenas costumbres y sobre todo que cumplan con su trabajo en sus cultivos. Roberto siembra en la chacra de sus padres, pero hace dos años ha comprado 2 cuadras con plantas frutales, y del mismo modo tiene anhelos se seguir adquiriendo más tierras. En estas chacras siembra café, porque dice ser mucho más rentable que los plátanos, pero la gran ventaja de los plátanos es que no se tiene que estar removiendo la tierra constantemente y estas plantas le duran más de 10 años en plena producción. Por ello que siempre trata de bien mantenerlas mediante el abonado correspondiente. Con el fin de captar mayores recursos tiene pensado trabajar en la ciudad, como chofer o quizás ponga un negocio, aun no lo tiene definido. Pero lo de lo que sí está seguro es que no solo espera tener ingresos económicos de sus cultivos. Roberto está muy feliz por tener la oportunidad de integrar este banco comunal, y más aun sabiendo que hay personas que hacen posible su crédito, hace compromisos de pagar puntualmente. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y lo han nombrado coordinador educativo. El dinero que solicita es para comprar plantitas de café, y la otra parte, espera que le alcance, será para comprar fertilizantes.
texts.en:
Robert is 38 years old, single, and lives in his own house. Agriculture is and has always been a strong part of his life. It sustains his siblings and the laborers who work for him in their eagerness to provide continuity to their customs and above all carry out the work of the land.

Robert plants in his parents’ small farm, but for the past two years he has been buying 2 blocks of fruit trees and would like to acquire more land. In this small farm, he plants coffee because he says it is more profitable than bananas, but the advantage of bananas is that they do not have to be transferred constantly and these plants last more than 10 years in full production. For that reason he always tries to maintain them well by credible means.

With the purpose of acquiring more resources, he is thinking of working in the city as a driver or perhaps setting up a business, even though it is not yet defined. But the one thing he is sure of is that he is not only waiting to have economic income from his crops.

Robert is very happy for having the opportunity to integrate this communal bank, and even more for knowing that there are people who make these loans possible. He is committed to making prompt payments. This is his first loan with MFP, and they have named him educational coordinator. The money he is requesting is to buy small coffee plants, and the other part will be used to buy fertilizer.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase coffee plants and fertilizer

loans.name: Cherche Lavie Group

texts.en:
The “Cherche Lavie” or “Search for Life” Group is made up of twenty-five male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their first loan, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their second loan. 

Eva N. is one of four representatives of the group. She is married with two young children. This hardworking mom sells a variety of things based on the season and the needs of her clients. She mostly sells charcoal and various fresh foods, including rice, beans, vegetables and cooking oils. She says that the loan was “from heaven” because the increased profits from her business allowed her to take care of her sickly daughter without having to worry about money. She dreams of doing greater things with the help of loans and hopes that one day she will sell her merchandise from a storefront. On behalf of Eva, Cherche Lavie and Esperanza, we thank you for your support.

loans.use: Buy wood, rice, beans, vegetables, and oils

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar Khizar Hayyat Group

texts.en:
Shamim Akhtar Baji has been a citizen of the city of Vehari, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is K. H. and he has been selling different vehicle wheels for the past 10 years. People come to him to buy wheels. 

Shamim Baji is the mother of three sons. All of her kids are getting their education from a school located near her house. Shamim Baji is a high determined lady. She wishes to give her sons a better education because she knows the value of it. She knows that education is a weapon that can take a person from problems to happiness. Shamim Baji sews clothes and takes orders from her neighbors. She charges $2 per dress. She used her income to pay off the school fees of her kids. Shamim Baji is now applying for a loan to buy more vehicle wheels for her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader for some other women from her locality. Nusrat Baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Kalsoom Baji wants a loan to buy more chickens for her chicken selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vehicle wheels to sell

loans.name: Rubina Aman Ullah Group
loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Salma Munir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Salma baji has owned a two room brick house in the city of Vehari, Pakistan for the past 18 years. She is married to M. H. and he has been selling cloth for 6 years. He buys cloth on demand of his customers,  from famous cities know for their fabrics like Multan and Lahore.
  
Salma baji is a mother with one son who is 5 years old. He studies in a school located near their house. Salma baji is able to meet much of her sons financial needs. She pays off his school fees from the profits of her seamstress business. Her husband is very happy with this support. She is applying for a loan to buy cloth to expand her husband’s cloth selling business. 

She is the group leader for several other women in her locality. Jamila baji and Yasmeen akhtar baji each want a loan to buy cloth to sell. Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell. Naseem begum baji wants a loan to buy iron to make iron rods to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cloth to sell

loans.name: Rahmat Ghulam Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Rahmat baji is the wife of G. M. and has been a resident in the city of Vehari, Pakistan for the past 11 years. People have been coming to her husband to buy clothes for six years.

Rahmat baji is a very hardworking lady. She gets up early and prepares breakfast for  her two sons and her daughter then gets them ready for school. After that she cleans the whole house and then starts sewing clothes. She sews clothes to pay off the school fees of her kids. She is applying for a loan to buy clothing to expand her husband’s clothing selling business. 

She is the group leader of several other women in her locality. Mafia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Saeeda baji wants a loan to buy clothing to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Kalsoom Begum Rustam Ali Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom begum baji has lived in the city of Vehari, Pakistan for 10 years. Her husband, R. A., has been raising and selling animals for the past 6 years. He raises livestock then resells them to butcher shops to earn profit. 

Kalsoom baji is the mother of two sons. Both of her sons study at a school located near their home. Kalsoom baji pays their school fees from her decorative embroidering business. She charges $3 for for an embroidered dress. Her embroidered designs attracts many customers. Her family is very happy with her supportive role. She is applying for a loan to buy goats for her husband’s livestock business. 

She is the group leader for several other women in her locality. Iram naz baji, Ameera baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy a sewing machine for their seamstress business. Neelam baji wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidering business.  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy livestock to raise and resell

loans.name: Nasim Akhtar Jeorge Qamar Group

texts.en:
Nasim Akhtar Baji is a married lady and has been a citizen of the city of Vehari, Pakistan for the past seven years. Her husband's name is J. Q., and he has been running a motor workshop in the community for the past six years. People come to his workshop to repair their vehicles. 

Nasim Baji is the mother of two sons, both of whom are enrolled in kindergarten. She is a highly determined lady, so she keeps herself busy by sewing clothes. She saves her income to be able to admit her son to a good school. Nasim Baji is applying for a loan to buy repairing tools for her husband’s motor workshop. 

She is the group leader for some other women from her locality. Irshad Naseem Baji wants a loan to buy an embroidery machine to prepare embroidered dresses to sell. Rehana Kosar Baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Razia Begum Baji, Alisha Baji, and Kalsoom Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy repairing tools for her husband's motor workshop

loans.name: Khalida Parveen Ghulam Rasool Group

texts.en:
Khalida Parveen baji, a resident of Vehari, Pakistan for the past 11 years, is the wife of G. R., who has been selling seasonal fruits for the past eight years, travelling to various areas and attracting customers by announcing his produce in a loud voice.

Khalida baji operates a clothes-sewing business, sewing on a daily basis. The purpose behind her enterprise is very noble. Fully aware of her husband’s struggles, she wants to share his financial burden so that he can perform his duties without tension. She is now applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to expand his business.

Khalida is the group leader of four other women from her community: Sumera baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business; Samina baji and G. Fatima baji each desire a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil and spices for their food business; Parveen baji seeks a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the others are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell.

loans.name: Sakina Nadir Ali Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a wife of N. A. and a citizen of a city named Vehari, Pakistan, for the past 10 years. She is the mother of two sons. Both of her kids are getting an education from a school located near her house. Her husband has been running a tea stall in the community for the past five years. People come to his stall for taking tea.

Sakina baji is involved in preparing embroidered clothes. She prepares embroidered dresses and sells them to the cloth markets and earns profit. She saves her income in a committee and plans to renovate the house from the committee amount. She is applying for a loan to buy tea, sugar and milk to expand her husband’s tea stall.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Zainab baji, Mussarat baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Zubaida baji and Bilquis baji each want a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for their food business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy tea, sugar and milk for a tea stall

loans.name: Coeurs Unis Group

texts.en:
The “Coeurs Unis” or “United Hearts” Group is made up of twenty male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying both their first and second loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their third loan. 

Dieusenie G. is one of four representatives of the group. She is a single mother with a two-year-old child. This hardworking mom sells a variety of merchandise, mostly foods and things related to cooking. Her small stand usually has cookies and small treats for the children as well as rice, beans, oils, and spices for the adults. She really appreciates that previous loans enabled her to buy her merchandise in bulk. Buying in bulk saves her money and expands her margin for profit. She hopes that the profit from her business will one day help her to build a house for her family and to send her daughter to school in a few years. On behalf of Dieusenie, Coeurs Unis and Esperanza, we thank you for your support.

loans.use: COOKIES, CANDY, OILS, FRUIT, VEGETABLES

loans.name: Union Cristiana 2 Group

texts.en:
This group of five is part of the Union Cristiana (Christian Union) Bank of Hope, which is joining Esperanza International, so they can fund businesses with micro loans.

Elta M. is the group coordinator. She speaks almost no Spanish, so a Creole translator was needed during her interview (luckily, one of the bank members speaks Creole and translated for her). She is expecting her first baby.

Elta needs to generate income more than ever, because now she is responsible for taking care of her child. Elta is in the business of selling clothes. She would like to purchase more clothing to sell with this loan, especially jeans and tennis shoes, which sell really well.

She is committed to working hard to make her business grow and to make sure that her baby is safe and has everything he or she needs (she still doesn’t know if the baby will be a boy or a girl). Please help this young mother-to-be and her fellow micro entrepreneurs in their ventures to make their way out of poverty. Thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Comuniddad Unida 7 Group

texts.en:
This group is the latest one to join the Comunidad Unida (United Community) Bank of Hope from La Barquita, in northern Santo Domingo.

Reyna E. is the group coordinator. She is single and has 2 teenage children, ages 16 and 19. The 16-year-old is still in high school.

Reyna sells silver jewelry, and will use this loan to purchase merchandise for her business. During her interview, Reyna explained that the items that sell best are earrings, rings, chains, and lockets. She mostly sells in her neighborhood, which includes her family, friends, and neighbors. In her spare time, Reyna likes to read, watch some TV, and listen to good music. She wants to “take her business to the top,” and in the future she would like to set up a boutique and beauty salon. On behalf of Esperanza International and this group of micro entrepreneurs, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Replenish merchandise

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer 7 Group

texts.en:
Marcia R. D. is the group coordinator for Group 7 of the Nuevo Renacer Bank of Hope. The five members of this group live in La Barquita, a large community in the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. This is the first loan they have requested, and they are very excited because they believe it will bring new life to their small businesses.

Marcia has 4 children, ages 22, 19, 17, and 11. She sells all kinds of clothing. She will use this loan to purchase the items she sells more frequently and are in big demand: undergarments, T-shirts, and bedding. She is usually very busy with her business and her housework. When she has some spare time, she likes to read the Bible, talk to her children, and help them with their homework.

She hopes this loan will take her one step closer to fulfilling her dream: owning a department store where she not only sells clothes, but all kinds of merchandise. On behalf of Esperanza International and this group of micro entrepreneurs, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Replenish her merchandise

loans.name: Peniel 3 Group

texts.en:
Group 3 from the Peniel Bank of Hope is ready to start their fourth loan cycle through Esperanza International, Kiva's partner. In the words of Luchi A., the group has done extremely well in their previous loan cycles and none of the members has been late on their payments. All the group members have also seen a significant increase in their profits after they started taking microloans.

Luchi’s mother and her three sisters are clients of Esperanza International. Luchi’s mother, Brigida, is the group coordinator for the group 2 from this same Bank of Hope. Her sister Tania is in this same group.

Luchi sells products from a catalog. She sells leather purses, shoes and belts. She explained to us that there is a new campaign coming up so she will use the loan to purchase merchandise from the new catalog in order to offer her clients the latest styles.

Luchi’s biggest challenge is her children’s education. This is why in spite of being so busy selling her catalog products and visiting her clients, she helps her children (two boys, ages 5 and 8) with their homework every day. She is a very dedicated businesswoman and mother with two goals: providing her children with the best education possible and, along with her catalog sales, having her own boutique/beauty salon.

On behalf of Esperanza International and this group of micro entrepreneurs, we’d like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for new campaign

loans.name: Union Cristiana 1 Group

texts.en:
The five members of the Union Cristiana Bank of Hope are ready to start their entrepreneurship adventure through Esperanza International. This is their first loan, and the group is very optimistic about using it to improve their business activities.

Wilkins C. is the group coordinator. He is the father of four boys, two of whom live with him, while the other two live with their mother. Wilkins used to sell fruits and vegetables as a street vendor, but has decided to set up a produce business at home because he would like to spend more time with his children. He wants to take better care of them and be more involved in their education.

Wilkins has set up a small produce stand at his home, with room to store produce and receive clients. He will use this first loan to buy the produce he plans to sell. When interviewed about his business, Wilkins explained that the products in highest demand are plantains, bananas, sweet potatoes, yucca, all salad vegetables, papayas, melons, oranges and tangerines. He goes to the market three times a week to restock. He hopes to stabilize his home business and eventually grow it into a mini market.

The Union Cristiana Bank of Hope and Esperanza International thank you for helping Wilkins grow his business and be a more present parent by working from home.

loans.use: purchase merchandise to sell from home

loans.name: Peniel 2 Group

texts.en:
Brigida S. and her group (Group 2 from the Peniel Bank of Hope) are starting their fourth loan cycle through Esperanza International, Kiva's partner. Brigida has four grown-up children; three female and one male. The females are all Esperanza clients through microloans.

Brigida has a small cafeteria at a local school. Right now she is facing a problem: She doesn’t have anything to keep the drinks she sells cold, so she has to buy ice blocks for this purpose. Sometimes the kids at the school don’t want to buy the water, juices and soft drinks she sells because they’re not cold, which is necessary in a tropical country like the Dominican Republic. So Brigida will use this loan to buy a freezer where she can store the drinks. She has already seen one that is on sale for a good price, she says.

When the school is closed, Brigida sells fried Johnny cakes and drinks at her house. In time, she would like to have her own colmado (convenience/grocery store) so she can sell in the same place permanently.

Thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: Buy a freezer for school cafeteria

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz U. is a rice farmer. Her farm is located in an uphill area in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She is 40 years old. She uses her harvest to raise her five children and to send them to school. Her husband, Sanny U., is also a farmer. Everyday, they go to their farm to check their crops to ensure a good harvest.

Aside from rice, they also grow vegetables in their backyard. They water their vegetable garden everyday. The profit she makes from selling vegetables is what she uses to pay for their other needs.

CEVI supports Beatriz in her business. Now, she enjoys the credit assistance, trainings, and insurance coverage after joining the CEVI credit program.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen A. grows rice and bananas. She and her husband are farmers and they have one child. They work on a 1.5 hectare farm which gives them enough food for the family. They enjoy working together under the heat of the sun, plowing the field, and touching the dirty soil so they can give their only child a better future.

Helen is asking for a loan of Php 14,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer to increase their harvest. The loan will help her also to start a new business. 

CEVI is a microfinance organization that helps people start and have a business in the Phillippines. CEVI provides credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to all their clients to help their small business to grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina H. is a 38-year-old mother of six. Her husband farms a small parcel of land, which is not enough to supply the daily food needs of the family. Gina sells the vegetables that they grow on their land to raise money for the transportation expenses of her two children who are in school.

She applied for a loan to buy two cattle to start a new venture. She wants to improve their standard of living through her proposed business. She wants to save money to provide for the basic needs of her children. She hopes to send all her children to school, and in the future would like to build a house that is more comfortable.

loans.use: To buy two cattle

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet L. grows rice and vegetables. She tills her 15-hectare land to easily feed and clothe her family. She is 44 years old and has five children. Her husband, Fernando L., is helping her manage their business. They dream to send all their children to college. With the help of CEVI credit assistance, they will be able to sustain their business and achieve higher yields.

She is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI, Kiva's partner. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and insecticides. In this way, she could ensure a quality harvest of her farm.

CEVI helps people to start and have a business. Like Juliet, other CEVI clients also receive not only credit assistance but also training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Ernesto M. is engaged in rice farming. He tills a three hectare piece of land that he inherited from his parents. Because of his farm, it is easy now for him to feed and clothe his family.  Ernesto says, "I am the head of the family, I need to work better for the future of my seven children.” 

Ernesto needs a loan of PHP 14,000 (USD 300) from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for his farm. The loan will truly give Ernesto a better yield so that he can continue to support the needs of his family. 

About CEVI

CEVI helps people start and maintain businesses. It helps clients by providing not just credit assistance, but trainings and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy fertlizers for the farm

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita S. is a 40-year-old mother of five. Her husband is her partner in operating their vegetable farm. The couple sometimes buys and resells their neighbor’s vegetables as well. They market some of the harvest in the nearby villages, but sell most of it on Sunday, which is market day in their town.

She applied for a loan as additional capital for her vegetable farm, to buy fertilizer and other materials needed to maintain the different vegetables they are growing. She wants to expand the farm to earn more money for the family. She hopes that in the future, they could plant a variety of high value crops to increase their production. She dreams of sending her children, who are now in elementary school, to college, and hopes to build a house in the village that is more accessible to the school her children attend.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and some materials needed in their vegetable farm.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry C. grows rice for a living. He tills 3 3/4 hectares of land that he inherited from his parents. He is also a fisherman. If he is not busy on the farm, he goes out fishing to catch some fish to eat. He is 53 years old and the harvest that he gets from the farm has made it easier for him to feed and clothe his family.

He is asking for a loan of PhP 13,000 ($275) from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs. In this way, he believes he will have a better yield. His harvest will be for his family's use, and the rest will be sold to rice traders in their village. 

CEVI helps people start and establish their own businesses. Through the credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all their clients, more and more people are able to make their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for the farm

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya G. is a married mother of five. She has four daughters and one son. Her eldest two daughters live in the countryside and work as herders. Her son lives and studies in the city of Erdenet. She lives with her husband and two youngest daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Together with her husband, she started a business in 2000, running a fruit stall at the Narantuul ("black market"), the biggest year-round outdoor market in Mongolia. She sells fruit at all times except winter. During the winter months, she sells frozen fruits, such as cranberries, and many types of jellies. Her husband buys a variety of fruits wholesale.

When she started her retail business, her family lived on someone else's plot of land, renting it for MNT 15,000 ($10). As a result of her retail business profits, she was able to buy a plot of land and her husband has built a little house on it. They are a hard-working, friendly and nice couple. With this loan, Altantuya will buy more fruit.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Batsayhan

texts.en:
Batsayhan S., 45, is a father of three sons and one daughter. His eldest son is a soldier in the army and his next oldest son is 19 and attends college. His youngest son is 14 and goes to an elementary school. Batsyahan's youngest is a three-year-old daughter who goes to kindergarten. His wife stays at home to take care of all of the family.

In 2000, Batsayhan ran a Russian car-supply business at a local car-supply market. Since he had been working as a driver and was driving mostly Russian vehicles, he was well-versed in the cars and their needs. Then he began to run his retail business, joining with a business partner to buy old cars and dismantle them to sell spare parts. Now he independently runs his business, and his profits have greatly increased since he struck off on his own. 

With this loan, Batsayhan will buy an old Russian vehicle to dismantle and sell for parts. He seems to be a humble, hard-working and friendly person.

loans.use: To buy an old Russian vehicle to dismantle and sell for parts

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar S., 33, is a married father of two daughters. His wife is a 32-year-old English teacher at an elementary school. His eldest daughter goes to elementary school, while the youngest one stays at home.

Ganbaatar's family moved from Umnugobi, one of Mongolia's southern provinces, to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, five years ago. As soon as he moved, he began to run a car-supply sales business at a local outdoor car-supply market named "Uguumur." His friends helped him to begin his business. During the spring, car-supply sales normally increase; therefore with this loan, he wants to buy more supplies.

This is Ganbaatar's first ever loan with the bank. He is a humble and friendly person.

loans.use: To buy car supplies

loans.name: Norjmaa

texts.en:
Norjmaa D. is a widowed, single mother of four. Her family lives in a "ger" district (a ger district is where many people have settled in this type of nomadic home, forming a sort of ad hoc suburb) on plot of land she owns. Her eldest son runs a transport business between Uvurhangay, his home province, and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

In 1999, Norjmaa began to run a meat-sales business at the local food market. She buys, butchers and sells four sheep a day. She earns between 250-1,000 MNT (0.17 cents-70 cents) per kilogram. Norjmaa's eldest daughter helps her business. Since she has no storage to freeze meat, she buys few animals during the summer but buys many sheep during the winter.

Norjmaa told us in Mongolian: "By running my retail business, I'm planning to enable my children to enroll in universities for their future career. I dream of having my own big supermarket!" (At the picture: Norjmaa is sitting at the left hand)

loans.use: To buy sheep meat

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya E., 45, is a single mother of three. Her eldest son is 17. He goes to high school and lives with his grandmother and grandfather. Her eldest daughter just got married and moved to her husband's place.

Enhtuya graduated from the Construction University of Russia as a carpenter, however, she has never worked as a carpenter. When Enhtuya was a little girl, her mother taught her how to make traditional dresses. She is a skillful person, and she sews a variety of traditional Mongolian clothing such as vests, "deel" (tunics) and hats and sells them. Before she started sewing clothes for buyers, she used to sew only for her children. Before national holidays and the recent Lunar New Year, she gets many orders from her customers. Now she wants to learn to make traditional costumes for actors.

Enhtuya's family lives on her brother's plot of land. She's working very hard to buy a plot of land for her family. She says, "My dream is to have my own tailor shop. And also I want to be able to provide my youngest son with as much money as he needs for his future life, tuition and career." With this loan, Enhtuya will invest in her business by buying silk and cotton.

loans.use: To buy silk and cotton

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en:
Tsend-Ayush D. is a 61-year-old, married woman. Her husband is handicapped and unable to work. The couple lives with their grandson in Baganuur, a little town located 200 km from the capital city of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar.

In 2000, she began to run a tiny business making finger food such as buuz (boiled dumplings) and huushuur (fried dumplings) at home and selling them to local market stalls as a lunch meal. She has been banking with XacBank, Kiva's partner micro-finance institution in Mongolia, for the last five years. She has many repeat customers since she makes delicious and healthy meals.

With this loan Tsend-Ayush plans to buy beef for her business. She has recently purchased a larger freezer and washing machine from her business profits. She wishes to live healthy and keep her tiny business as long as she can.

loans.use: To buy beef for her business

loans.name: Tumen-Ulziy

texts.en:
Tumen-Ulziy D., 54, is married to a welder. They have one son, a university student. They live in the town of Baganuur, located 200 kilometers from the capital city of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar.

Tumen-Ulziy has been working as a hairdresser in the White Mountain hair salon for the last 25 years. For the first 15 years she was an employee, but over the last 10 years, she has been renting a space at the salon and working for herself.

Because of her long experience, she has developed many repeat customers over the last five years who keep coming especially to see her. With this loan, she is planning to replenish her hair-cutting supplies. She will buy scissors, combs, a blow dryer, a curling iron, etc. Tumen-Ulziy's dream is to see her son become a successful person.

loans.use: To buy hair-cutting supplies

loans.name: Jona

texts.en:
Jona D. C. is a rice grower. She is 26 years old and has 2 children. She also maintains a vegetable and flower garden in her backyard. She has been a farmer since she married her husband, Helbert D. C.. She owns a 9-hectare farm in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She uses her harvest to support her family's needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 11,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and herbicides. She has been a CEVI client for 2 years now. She believes that her loan will bring her a good harvest. The loan will truly help her increase her yield. This also will help her start a new business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start up and run a business on their own. They teach people to earn a living for their family. They provide credit assistance, training and insurance coverage to help their clients sustain and grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth P. grows rice in her farm. She is 42 years old and has 7 children. She has been a CEVI client for 2 years now. She owns and tills 7-hectare of land which she uses to feed and clothe her family. She dreamed of having all her children to college so that, when they are older, they will get better jobs to support their future family. CEVI helps her sustains her business more.

She is asking a loan of Php 9,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and seeds. The loan will truly help her improve her yield. In this way, she can offer better support for the whole family. She is also interested in looking for some other line of business to augment their income still more. CEVI helps people start up and run their own business. Through CEVI, more and more people are able to access easy credit to support their businesses. CEVI also gives their clients training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolanda V., at 70, earns her own living. Her husband died 4 years ago, leaving her with 8 children, of whom 7 now have families of their own. Her youngest is currently working as an oversees contract worker. As a parent, she knew too well the burden of managing the family's daily expenses against the family's income. So to help her extended family, she had to find ways to earn. Through her small vegetable garden and a variety store, Yolanda was able to cope with her personal expenses and give a portion to her children. She is now applying for her eighth loan from HSPFI amounting to PHP 15,000.00 for additional capital for her current business.

loans.use: To purchase goods for a sari-sari store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose has owned a small food store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for the past 8 years. She belongs to Tushikamane group (Group code 2006).  Every day she works at her business for 10 hours. 

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  


Rose is married, and has six children, ages 20, 17, 10, 5, 4 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle F. is a 31-year-old mother of three. She is presently engaged in food vending. Her live-in partner is a farmer who helps raise her children. 
Michelle applied for a loan to buy a piglet to raise and some fish to sell. She hopes to establish a stall for her fish and a piggery for her pigs. She wants to increase her income in order to provide for the basic needs of her family.
She wishes to save money for the education of her children.  (One child is currently in elementary school, while the other two are in high school.) She also hopes to build a better house in the future.

loans.use: To buy one piglet to raise and some fish to sell.

loans.name: Marito

texts.en: Marito T., a husband and a father of two kids, does his very best to provide for the needs of his family. At 53, he is determined, enthusiastic, and able to give a better life for them. His main source of income is his small variety store handled by his wife. He spends his time fishing at night and driving a pedicab during the day. Because of Marito's strong desire to see his children finish their studies, along with his wish to quit renting a house and purchase a small home of his own, HSPFI is helping him fulfill his dreams through HSPFI savings and loans. Marito is applying for his seventh loan amounting to PHP 15,000.00 (US$325) in order to raise capital for his variety store as well as to provide maintenance for his pedicab and boat.

loans.use: for pedicab maintenance and stocks for his variety store

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa E. owns a small "sari-sari" (Tagalog for "various kinds") store. She is also engaged in making baskets, which gets additional income for her family. She is 46 years old and has seven children. She started her business in 2001. Now, she still has a store and still makes good quality baskets which she uses to feed and clothe her family.

She is asking a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI, Kiva's partner. She will use the loan to buy additional materials for making baskets and merchandise for her store. The loan will truly help her attract more customers and grow her business more.

CEVI helps people start and have their own business. They provide all their clients not just credit assistance but also training and insurance coverage to help their small business to grow.

loans.use: To buy stock for her sari-sari store and basket-making materials

loans.name: Realonda

texts.en:
Realonda C. assists her husband through the buying and selling of dressed chicken parts. She buys and sells every 15th day of the month payable within 15 days. For their daily consumption, her husband works as a personal driver every day. 

Her two children are both studying. But it is not easy for the kids to study because they don't have electricity connection. Through the previous received HSPFI microfinance loan they were able to have electricity installed. Her dream is to let her children finish their studies. To materialize this dream, she wants to apply for a loan amounting to PHP15,000 to finance her business.

loans.use: purchased  dressed chicken for her buy and sell business.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria has been a business woman in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Tushikamane group loan (Group code 2006). Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. 

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  


Gloria is 32 years old, married, and has three children: ages between 7 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Ukombozi Group

texts.en:
Victoria M. has owned a small food vendor store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for three years. She works 12 hours a day at her business and currently earns an average monthly profit of $400. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She hopes to grow her business by increasing her profit through this loan.  

Victoria is 40 years old and married. She has three children, ages 20, 18, and 11.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Tabu S., who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items to grow her business.

loans.name: Arline

texts.en:
Arline B. raises pigs in her back yard. She is 54 years old and has one child. When she isn't busy in her piggery, she cooks food. She sells the pigs in her village: her customers come in from the nearby town to buy them, and she receives many calls from them when she is preparing to sell her pigs. She earns a lot of money from hog raising, which is why she wants to expand her business with the help of CEVI.

She is requesting a loan of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets and expand her business. Aside from helping to purchase pigs and foods, the loan will also help Arline start a new business. 

CEVI heps people start and run their own businesses. They provide their clients with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help their businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed.

loans.name: Majengo "a"street Group

texts.en:
Zaituni I. has owned a small food vendor store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for eight years. She works at her business every day. She belongs to the Majengo "A" street group loan. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She hopes to grow her business by increasing her profit through this loan.

Zaituni is 45 years old and married. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Pili M., who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Majengo "a" Street Group

texts.en:
Oliva has been a businesswoman in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 8 years. She belongs to Majengo "A" sreet group loan. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. 

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  


Oliva is 34 years old and married.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Meresiana, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to expand her business

loans.name: Mjengo "a" Street Group

texts.en:
Kulwa S. has been a businesswoman in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for seven years. She works 10 hours a day at her business. She belongs to the Majengo "A" street group loan. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her stock. She hopes to grow her business by increasing her profit through this loan.
 
Kulwa is 26 years old and married. She has two children, ages 10 and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Ester N., who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela S. is a pig farmer. She is 72 years old and has six children. Despite her age, she is still strong and able to run her business. She enjoys raising pigs. Marcela still helps her children and their families: her profit goes toward their needs as well as the educational fees of her grandchildren.  She also sells "bibingka" (rice cake) in her village. Bibingka is a very popular Filipino delicacy.

She is asking for a loan of Php 23,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to expand her business by buying more piglets and more feed as well as improving her pig fence. The loan will help Marcela raise more pigs.

CEVI helps people start and run their own businesses. They provide their clients with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help their businesses grow. Through CEVI’s microfinance efforts, people have the opportunity to better support their families. CEVI has been providing and expanding these services for 10 years.

loans.use: To purchase feed for pigs and piglets.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria M. is a 39-year-old mother of six. She is married to a farmer; the land they cultivate was inherited from her parents. Gloria and her husband grow rice and vegetables to support the basic needs of their family.

She has applied for a loan to buy certified seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides. She hopes to increase production through these materials. If the harvest is good, she hopes to save enough money to be able to buy farming materials on her own next time, without the use of a loan.

She hopes to send her children to school and eventually to build a better house for her family.

loans.use: To buy certified seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana has owned a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 3 years. She belongs to Wema group loan (Group code 2006). Every day she works at her business. 

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her current stock. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  


Ana is married, and has three children: ages 18, 16 and 8.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her current stock

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
She is a woman with courage and even at 60 year old she is willing to pursue her business. She is married and blessed with 6 children who will help her manage her business.

	Clarita is engaged in processing peanut brittle. She started the business in 1999 with an initial capital of only P500.00. The people living in the municipality serve as her customers. Today she is also consigning to other places in Hamtic and Dao, buying and selling bananas and does food vending to help with the family's daily needs and the education of her children.

	She aspires that someday she will be the producer/manufacturer of different types of food, alleviate poverty in her family, and send her children to school so they can find a stable job in the future.

loans.use: To purchase food processing ingredients

loans.name: Arcel

texts.en:
Arcel B. is a cook and owns a small eatery in her village. She is 38 years old and has only one child. Her husband, Aristarco helps her manage the business. Together, they work very hard to provide a good future for their child. Prior to this business, she sold dry goods. But she wound up with a food business because she thinks that it is a better and more profitable business.

She is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional stock and to renovate her eatery. The loan will help Arcel attract more customers and earn more income for her family.

CEVI is helping people start and run their own business. They don't just provide loans to people; they also give training and insurance coverage to help their clients succeed in their business.

loans.use: To buy additional stock and renovate the eatery

loans.name: Priscila

texts.en:
Priscila is a 51 year old food and vegetable vendor. She has been in this business since her first loan with ASHI. She sells vegetables from her backyard, has ventured into buying and selling, and makes Bandi (made of young coconut meat with muscovado sugar). 
	
	In addition to her food and vegetable vending business, she is also starting to raise hogs. Her loan will be used to purchase inventory and as start-up capital for her new business: raising hogs. Actually raising hogs is not new to her; she has lots of experience and ideas on raising hogs. 

	She dreams of expanding this business and having a space/stall in her town public market. She also dreams that her children will stay in school until they finish their studies. She knows that ASHI gave a woman like her an opportunity to have access to capital and gave her self-confidence and the realization that she is a woman to be trusted.

loans.use: To purchase of  a head of piglets, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ukombozi Group

texts.en:
Salome has owned a small grocery store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 8 years. She belongs to Ukombozi group loan (Group code 2003). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 350. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more commodities for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Salome is 37 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 9, and 5. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Emmy, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa D. is a 37-year-old mother of four. She is married to a checker and bagger who works in the airport. Luisa is a barangay (township) councillor, a job which pays her some money. However, their combined income is not enough to support their family’s needs, so she also raises pigs to earn additional money.

She has applied for a loan to buy two piglets in order to establish a piggery in the future. She hopes to supply meat in their locality, a high quality meat she will produce out of the materials she will buy from her loan.

She dreams of building a better future for her children, by sending them to a university.

loans.use: To buy two pigs

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen A. is 33 years old. He is married with one child who is six months old. He lives in a village called ‘Ntranko’ which means ‘Don’t go beyond the next villages’. He said that in olden days, the community was hospitable so when you came you would not like to move to the surrounding settlements.

He is a chemical seller and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, malaria drugs, etc. in his neighborhood. Many local people use his drugs as first aid and cure when they are sick. He has been in business for three years now and he is only person who supplies pharmaceutical products in the community.

Stephen wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of drugs, including others that are frequently requested by his customers. He hopes to raise good income to take care of his family.
