He hopes to receive GHS 600 to make business progress by restocking his inventory. This would enable him to save more to support his children in school. Stephen belongs to a village bank called ‘Romans’.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Jane has owned a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 10 years. She belongs to Amani group loan (Group code 2005). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 300. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her sock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Jane is married and has three children: ages 21, 20 and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Bupe, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: Christina's Group

texts.en:
Christina is a milk and eggs seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya.. She belongs to Amani group loan (Group code 2005). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 600. Every day she works at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more milk and eggs for re-sale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Christina is married, and has seven children: ages 37, 27, 28, 22, 18, 17 and 15. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Upendo, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more milk and eggs for re-sale

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. is 48 years old and is a consistently well-performing member of ASHI. She owns a variety store and has been able to maintain her business for almost six years. She had only P 110.00 as starting capital, which she used to purchase breads and candies. 

She is married and blessed with five children who inspired her to pursue her dreams. Her requested loan of P 30,000.00 will be an important tool for her variety store. It will allow her to purchase additional stocks and will help her to get discounts by buying in volume.

Zenaida dreams of expanding her variety store into groceries so that her business can help sustain the academic needs of her children until they finish their studies or become employed.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for variety store.

loans.name: Anamon

texts.en:
Anamon H., 48, is a mother of four children who are in school. She is very hard-working and resourceful. She lives with her husband and children in Bekwai, a suburb of Obuasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Anamon has been working with her husband in the charcoal business for the past three years. Her husband travels to the villages to place orders of charcoal in bulk, a supply which lasts a month. Anamon trades the charcoal in her neighborhood and sells to her customers in the marketplace of Bekwai. 

Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. She wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to pay her children educational fees. She would be grateful for your assistance. She is a member of a village trust bank group called ‘Anamon H.’, named after her. She also hopes to receive GH¢700 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of charcoal.

loans.name: Asana

texts.en:
Asana N. is 50 years old. She is married with three children, all of whom are attending school. The first child is studying at a nursing school, the second is studying at a teacher training college, and the third is in the senior school. Asana lives with her husband at Bekwai in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Her husband works with Ghana Telecommunication (GT), now acquired by Vodafone UK. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits, etc. in the local community. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supply of the above items to expand her business. 

She maintains that no member of her family is capable to support her financially because they are also facing hardships like her. Asana hopes that the income she would make from the expanded business will enable her to provide quality education to her children. Asana belongs to a village bank called “Yikoshai Allah”, which means ‘Power belongs to God’. She hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted food spices, washing soaps and powders, etc.

loans.name: Gerlita

texts.en:
Gerlita is 45 year old woman with a motorcycle transport business. Her service is very much needed by the people living in the municipality of Hamtic, and especially the villagers of Malandog. She started her business with a P 5000 loan from ASHI, and now owns two motorcycles. She earns extra money by raising Bangus fish fry. The extra income is a big help in meeting her daily needs and educating her children.

Gerlita dreams of adding a sidecar to her motorcycle to make it into a tricycle. She would like to use the additional passenger income for her children’s education so that they, too, will one day have good and stable jobs.

loans.use: purchasing the needed materials for motorcycle

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary S. has been trading in the local market of Bekwai zongo community in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where she stays with her family. She is 43 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a trader, and two of her children are still in school. She is a busy petty trader who sells tomatoes and other foodstuffs like beans, onions, pepper, carrots, green pepper and salad leaves in the zongo community. She strives very hard to make ends meet for her family.

She does not have sufficient working capital to run the business, which retards her business progress. With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory and revive the business. Mary belongs to a village bank called “Bamali Allah” which means ‘It is only God who can do it’. She hopes to receive GH¢700 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase increased stock of palm oil, tin tomatoes, corn dough, onions, beans, dried fish, etc.

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
Abdul R. is 36 years old. He is married and the father of six children. Abdul supports his family through the proceeds from his business. All his children are in school. Abdul lives with his wife at Bekwai in the Ashanti region of Ghana. It is his daily dream to provide quality education for his children to give them better future life.

Abdul owns and operates a grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc. He has a good relationship with his customers. He wants to use the loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil to increase his stock of goods. With increased stocks of different varieties, he hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of his children. He hopes to repay the loan in due time because he believes the loan would boost his business growth. His picture was taken when he was visited at his business site. He hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking his inventory. This would enable him to save more to support his children in school.

Abdul belongs to a village bank called ‘Ayi Adakyew’ which means ‘Do what you are doing now well because of tomorrow’.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted spices, washing soaps and powders, etc.

loans.name: Mamuna

texts.en:
Mamuna F. is a 30-year-old trader; she is single and the mother of two children. Both her children are in school. She resides at Bekwai in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

She is a very resourceful single mother whose hard effort brings livelihood for the family. Mamuna supports her kids through the sale of clothing and fried yams. She sells garment cloths and lace materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. She treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods. For lack of adequate working capital, Mamuna buys only a little stock of lace materials and garments cloth and sells through hawking. For this reason, she is requesting loan support for her business to make her business progress. She sells fried yams just in front of a store in the community where she lives.

She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk supplies of lace materials, garment cloths, and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with quality education. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Soyeya’ which means ‘Love’. She hopes to receive GHS 900 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk, yams, cooking oil, and fish etc.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
A. Theresa is 24 years old. She is married and the mother of three kids. She lives in Bekwai Zongo community with her husband. Her husband is a cleaner at the public toilet at the community. Zongo is a place which is dominated by Muslims.

A. Theresa is a local manufacturer of palm kernel oil. Palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernels. The palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes like frying fish, making local soaps, and pastries. She produces and supplies oil to food vendors to prepare their meals. However, her production is on the low side as a result of low working capital to afford a machine for processing.

A. Theresa wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm kernels, three additional pots, and an electric milling machine to reduce the drudgery of using manual effort to help produce oil in larger quantities. She believes the loan will enable her to save more toward her children's education.

A. belongs to a village bank called ‘Bamali Allah’ which means ‘It is only God who can do it’. She hopes to receive GHS 600 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bags of palm kernel, three big pots, etc.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha Y. is 27 years old. She is a married woman with two children. One is schooling whiles the new-born is still breastfeeding. She lives with her family at Bekwai in the Ashanti region of Ghana. For the past three years, Martha has been baking bread to provide for her household. In spite of the challenges she faces, she bakes sugar bread, wheat bread, etc., and retails it to her customers. She says, she makes sure her food quality meets her customers' expectations. Her customers book their order in advance and before they come it is ready. She also retails to individuals for their morning breakfast.

She says the price of commodities is increasing which is making it difficult to buy more raw materials from the market. And the daily demand for bread is high. She says she bakes at most 800 loaves of bread in a day. Martha needs the loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, margarine, milk, and firewood etc. She said your assistance would be most welcome.

Martha belongs to a village bank called ‘Bamali Allah’ which means ‘It is only God who can do it’. She hopes to receive GHS 600 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast, firewood etc.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim M. is 48 years old. He is married with three children. He lives at Bekwai, together with his family. Currently all his children are in school. He is a chemical seller and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonics, pain killers, malaria drugs etc. in his neighborhod. Many local people use his drugs as first aid and cure when they are sick. He has been in business for twelve years now and he is only person who supplies pharmaceutical products in the community. His chemist's shop is registered to operate by Ghana pharmaceutical council.

Ibrahim wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of drugs, to include others that are frequently requested by his customers. He hopes to raise good income to take care of his family. He hopes to receive GHS 900 to make business progress by restocking his inventory. This would enable him to save more to support his children in school. Ibrahim belongs to a village bank called ‘Ayi Adakyew’ which means ‘Do what you are doing now well because of tomorrow’.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en: Jamila B. is 50 years old. She is divorced and has two children. All her children are still in school. She owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk and biscuits etc. It has been her dream to expand by adding other food stuffs to her existing products. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school. She also hopes to receive GH¢900 to restock her inventory. Jamila belongs to a village bank called ‘Ayi Adakyew’ which means ‘Do what you are doing now well because of Tomorrow’.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water, and boxes of biscuit etc.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu M. is married and the mother of seven children who are currently in school. She is a forty year old trader who trades in charcoal, bags of rice, and vegetable oil. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes, and she has been in this business for the past 6 years.

Through this business, she has supported two of her kids' completion of senior high school. Ramatu obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Bekwai in the Ashanti region where she lives, and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of charcoal, vegetable oil, and bags of rice to increase her stock. She believes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to provide for the educational needs of her children. She hopes to receive GH¢800 to restock her inventory. Ramatu belongs to a village bank called ‘Ayi Adakyew’ which means ‘Do what you are doing now well because of Tomorrow’. Her husband is also a farmer who deals in food crops.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of charcoal, cooking oil, and bags of rice.

loans.name: Belawu

texts.en:
Belawu M. is 50 years old. She is widowed and has four children. All her children are still in school. She owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood where she sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, and biscuits, etc. She also sells other food stuffs like tomatoes, smoked fish, dried fish, onions, pepper, etc.

It has been her dream to expand her shop by adding other food stuffs to her existing products. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, tomatoes, smoked fish, dried fish, onions, spices, groundnuts etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school. She hopes to receive GH¢900 to restock her inventory. Belawu belongs to a village bank called ‘Bamali Allah’ which means ‘It is only God who can do it’.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water, and boxes of biscuit etc.

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en: B. Ahmed is 32 years old. He sells clothes in the town of Kabwohe and has 10 years of experience in this enterprise. He hopes to enlarge his business with the help of this loan. Ahmed is married and has three children who are well looked after. Ahmed’s other sources of income are coffee and a banana plantation that his wife manages.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for his shop.

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
Luis vive en casa de sus padres en la calle Valentín Abecia de la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz , es estudiante de la escuela Hotelera en el área de Gastronomía; el crédito que solicita es para pagar sus estudios y continuar estudiando, trabaja por las noches en una Discoteca de garzón con cuyos ingresos se mantiene y puede solventar sus estudios.

No es cliente de Impro, pero por la actividad y el carácter social puede acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Luis lives at home with his parents on Valentin Abecia Street in the Alto San Pedro area of the city of La Paz. He is studying food services at a hotel school, Escuela Hotelera. The loan he is requesting is to pay for his studies and to continue studying. He works at night as a waiter in a disco using the income to support himself and to complete his studies.

He is not client of Impro, but he meets the requirements to qualify for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay tuition to continue studying food services at the hotel school in La Paz

loans.name: Scuratcov

texts.en: I. is 32 years old and works as a truck driver.  He likes this work because even as a child he dreamed of driving big trucks cross country and having the opportunity to see many beautiful places. A few weeks ago his truck developed problems with the electronic system. This presents a big problem for I., because now it is risky for him to drive. With a loan from Microinvest he can repair the truck and be ready to go again.

loans.use: to repair electronic system

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es:
Concepción trabaja en la sub-alcaldía de Mecapaca y los fines de semana se dedica a la elaboración de planillas para partidos de fútbol de salón; es soltera e independiente ya que es la única que genera ingresos para poder solventar sus gastos de estudios, alimentación y otros gastos 
Vive en la zona de Tembladerani de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus padres. 
El crédito será destinado para capital de inversión ( instalación de una tienda para juegos en la red de Internet)..
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito.
texts.en:
Conception M. works at the mayor's office of Mecapaca and on the weekends she makes money keeping score sheets for indoor soccer games. She is single and she supports herself. She is the only one that makes money to pay her education, food and other expenses. She lives in Tembladerani in the city of La Paz, at her parent’s house. The loan will be used to invest in a new business, a store for people to play games on the Internet. This is the third time that she has received a loan and her record qualifies her as a trustworthy borrower.

(Translated by Edith of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The cost to install a a store for people to play games on the Internet

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.ru: Шахнозе 26 лет. Она не замужем, нигде не работает. Вместе со своей матерью Шахноза торгует на местном рынке, и ассортимент ее товаров включает в себя мелкие товары. Доход от торговли весомо пополняет семейный бюджет Шахнозы и ее родителей. Недавно она приобрела новый киоск, который является одновременно и камерой хранения для ее товаров. Оборотные средства ее бизнеса уменьшились и поэтому Шахноза решила получить займ. Новый займ собирается погасить в течении 2 месяцев.
texts.en:
Shahnoza is 26 years old. She is unmarried and is self-employed. She sells an assortment of products, including small novelties, at the local market with her mother. The income from sales is a weighty part of Shahnoza and her parent's household budget. Recently she obtained a new stall which also serves as locked storage for her goods. The business's working capital declined, so Shahnoza decided to request a loan. The loan will be repaid over 2 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Idris

texts.ru: Джалолову Идрису исполнилось 40 лет, женат и имеет 3 детей. Занимается предпринимательством на центральном рынке города Исфары. В отличии от многих предпринимателей Идрис знает как привлечь покупателей в свой маленький магазинчик. То как разложен его товар, как он общается с покупателями показывает, что он имеет постоянных покупателей. В его бизнесе ему помогает его племянник,  который заменяет Идриса во время его отсутствия. Чтобы расширить свой бизнес Идрис решил получить займ и для этого обратился в Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Idris J. is 40 years old, married, and has three children. He is an entrepreneur in the Isfara central market. Unlike many entrepreneurs, Idris knows how to attract customers to his small store. The way he lays out his goods, and how he interacts with customers show that he has regular buyers. His nephew helps with the business and takes over when Idris is gone. In order to expand his business Idris decided to request a loan, and came to Microinvest to do so.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mehrihon

texts.ru: Мехрихон уже получала займ на КИВА. В прошлый раз полученный займ она вложила в свой бизнес и получила хороший доход. Это был школьный сезон и так как Мехрихон имеет хороший опыт в бизнесе она смогла рационально распределить полученный займ. Для дальнейшего расширения своего бизнеса Мехрихон собирается получить новый займ.
texts.en:
Mehrihon has already received a loan through Kiva. She invested the last loan in her business and received a good return. That was during the school season and since Mehrihon has good experience in business she allocated the loan money sensibly. Mehrihon plans to obtain another loan for further expansion of her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Abduhakim

texts.ru: Абдухакиму 33 года, он женат. Вместе с женой они воспитывают 2 детей. Вот уже несколько лет они занимаются мелким предпринимательством. Абдухаким нигде не работает и поэтому предпринимательство является основным доходом семьи. С Микроинвест Абдухаким сотрудничает уже три года и полученные займы внесли заметные изменения в его бизнес. Раньше они ездили по окрестным базарам, теперь приобрели маленький киоск и торгуют постоянно на одном месте. Ассортимент его товаров огромный, Абдухаким имеет множество постоянных клиентов. Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса он планирует получить новый займ и собирается приобрести новый ассортимент товаров.
texts.en:
Abduhakim is 33 years old and married. He and his wife are raising two children. For several years they have run a small business. As Abduhakim has no other job, the business is his family's main source of income. He has been working with MicroInvest for three years and the loans he has received have made a significant impact on his business. Previously they traveled to neighboring bazaars, however now they have purchased a small kiosk and sell from a fixed location. Due to his broad assortment of goods, Abduhakim has many regular customers. To further develop his business, Abduhakim plans to take out a new loan to purchase a selection of new merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory

loans.name: Annor

texts.en:
Annor A. is the father of five children, one male and four females. The first born, a girl, is currently in senior high school. The rest are in junior high and primary school. Annor is dark in complexion. He is forty-two years old and runs a cold storage business with his wife. Annor lives with the family in a commercial town called Bekwai, close to Obuasi (a gold mining town) in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The majority of the inhabitants of Bekwai are into commercial activities. 

Annor procures his goods wholesale from big cold storage operators in Kumasi, a nearby city, and sells at retail prices to his customers, most of whom are food vendors. His cold storage business is situated right at the center of the local market square. Annor says he makes good sales because of this strategic location. He has been in business for ten years. He wants more working capital in order to increase the quantity of goods he buys. It is his dream to put up a house for his family.

loans.use: To procure fresh fish and meat

loans.name: Fahriddin

texts.ru: Фахриддин уже несколько лет занимается частным предпринимательством. Направление его бизнеса – это продажа электротоваров: электропровода, розетки, лампочки, предохранители и тп. Для него это является основным источником дохода в его семейном бюджете. Фахриддину исполнилось 30 лет, он женат и имеет уже троих детей. Фахриддин планирует развивать свой бизнес и далее, для этого необходимо дополнительные средства. Полученный займ собирается потратить на приобретение оптовой партии электропроводов.
texts.en:
Fahriddin A. has been a private entrepreneur for several years. His area of business is electronics sales: electric cords, outlets, light bulbs, fuses, etc. It provides the primary source of income for his family. Fahriddin is 30 years old, married, and already has three children. He plans to further develop his business, and will need additional funds. The loan will be spent on the wholesale purchase of electronics goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: wholesale purchase of electronics

loans.name: Ussif

texts.en:
Ussif S. is married and the father of three children, all females. He is thirty-eight years old. His first born child is in senior high school, and the others are in the primary school. He lives with his family in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Bekwai, close to Obuasi (a gold mining town) in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The majority of the inhabitants of Bekwai are into commercial activities. Ussif is a tailor by profession.

He buys fabrics and accessories from Kumasi and sews for retail sale. He procures the materials and sews for people who place an order, but he does not charge a deposit. His shop is situated right at the main entrance of the local market square. As a result, Ussif says he wins many customers. He has been in business for seventeen years and has trained a number of apprentices who have graduated. He has some apprentices who are still in training. Ussif says he wants a loan to buy a variety of materials in bulk. It is his dream to put up a house for his family and to give his children the best education possible.

loans.use: To buy fabric in bulk

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is forty-eight years old. She is married and has five children, two females and three males. The oldest daughter is a seamstress. The other children are in the senior high and junior high schools. Janet lives with her family in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Bekwai, close to Obuasi (a gold mining town) in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The majority of the inhabitants of Bekwai are into commercial activities. 

Janet is a trader who deals in underwear such as panties, brassieres, socks, slips, etc. to help provide for the family. She buys the goods in Kumasi. She sells house-to-house except for Wednesday, market day, when she sells in the market. Janet has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy more goods. It is her dream to give her children the best education possible.

loans.use: To buy undergarments

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36 year old Naomi D. from Mwanza.  She is married. She is also responsible for supporting two orphan dependents. Naomi has been running a poultry business since 2008. D. has a Poultry/kuku business. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially among SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. She works at the business for 4 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Naomi currently earns about 160USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy chicks to raise and resell. In the future, she plans to expand her business. D. thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more chicks raise and resell

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Mwajuma S. from Mwanza. She is single with two children, between the ages of 2 and 12 years old. Mwajuma S. has been running a grocery business since 1997. Mwajuma's grocery is a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof. She sells general items such as beer, soda and water. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Mwajuma currently earns about 200USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more drinks such as beer, water and soda. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mwajuma thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks such as beer, water and soda for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace Y. is thirty eight years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, three girls and three boys.. According to her, one of her children is learning a trade. The rest are attending senior high and junior high schools. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Bekwai, close to Obuasi (a gold mining town, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The majority of the inhabitants of Bekwai are into commercial activities. Her husband is a teacher by profession. Grace is a bread baker. She procures bags of flour, sugar, margarine, etc from shops in her community at retail prices. She would like a larger working capital so that she could travel and buy directly from wholesalers at more attractive price. Grace supplies the bread to retailers and beverage sellers in her community. She has been baking bread for seven years and now wants a loan to expand her business. It is her dream to give her children the best of education.

loans.use: To procure bags of flour and ingredients to make bread to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Elizabeth N. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of 6 and 14 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents do not take care of them.

Elizabeth has been running a beauty salon since 2007. This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee.

Elizabeth currently earns about $300 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy more salon products like weaving, short hair, long hair and curly hair. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Elizabeth thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more salon products like weaving, short hair, long hair and curly hair

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet S. is 45 years old. She is a divorced mother of two children, both of whom are females. According to her, the first daughter has completed senior high and is awaiting results while the other daughter is currently in her final year at the senior high school.

She lives with her daughters in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Bekwai, close to Obuasi (a gold mining town) in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The majority of the inhabitants of Bekwai are into commercial activities. She says it has not been easy providing for the children alone, especially their school fees.

Janet is a trader. She deals in printed textiles such as wax prints, fancy prints, java prints, lace, etc. to make some income to support her children. She buys the goods from the textile depot in Kumasi. She sells under a shed in the market square.

Janet has been in business for as long as 20 years. She wants a loan to buy more textiles. It is her dream to sponsor her daughters to the university level.

loans.use: To procure printed textiles

loans.name: Pendo

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Pendo M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 9 years old.

Pendo has been running a tailoring business since 2007. Her business is to purchase vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and make them into clothing, mainly for women.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Pendo currently earns about $180 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides). In the future, she plans to expand her business. Pendo thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides)

loans.name: Maria Calixta

texts.es: La Señora María Calixta S. tiene la edad de 52 años, su estado civil es casada. No tiene hijos. La actividad económica de Doña María es la venta de leña y frijoles cocidos. Hace más de treinta y cinco años que se dedica este negocio Doña María inicio esta actividad por su Mama por lo que esta es una buena fuente de ingresos y le gusto mantenerla. Los propósitos de Doña María son de mantener su negocio por que es la única manera para sobrevivir de su familia. El financiamiento es utilizado para capital de trabajo ya que tiene que realizar la compra de productos como leña, cuajada y carne. Sus deseos son de establecer otro negocio para conseguir ingresos extras para su familia. La cantidad es de C$ 8.000 córdobas.
texts.en:
Maria Calixta S. is 52, married and does not have children. Maria sells firewood and cooked beans. Maria has had this business for more than 35 years. She started the business for her mother because it is a good source of income and she would like to keep it. Maria intends to maintain her business as it is the only way for her family to survive. The loan will be used as working capital to buy firewood, cheese and meat. She wants to establish another business in order to gain additional income for her family. The loan requested is C$8,000 córdobas.

Translated from Spanish by Deborah Delzell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Жена Рустама раньше являлась активной клиенткой Микроинвест несколько лет. Сам Рустам ранее был на заработках в России, после приезда стал помогать жене по бизнесу. Жена Рустама занималась куплей продажей сухофруктов, затем стала продавать рис. Посоветовавшись супруги решили арендовать маленький киоск посреди рынка и включили в ассортимент растительное масло, макароны, рис и чай. Теперь торговля пошла лучше и стало много постоянных клиентов. Сейчас Рустам планирует получить новый займ и прибрести оптом рис, так как цена на него сейчас приемлема.
texts.en:
Rustam's wife was an active Microinvest client for several years. He himself previously traveled to Russia for work, but after his return, he began helping his wife with the business. She worked in dry fruit sales, and later switched to selling rice. After some discussion, the couple decided to rent a small stall in the market and expand their inventory to include oil, noodles, rice, and tea. Now sales have improved and there are many regular customers. Rustam plans to obtain another loan and buy rice wholesale, since the price is currently fair.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: wholesale purchase of rice

loans.name: Bihabiba

texts.ru: Бихабиба занимается бизнесом более 15 лет. С самого начала она занимается куплей продажей риса. За товаром ездит по окрестностям и на оптовый рынок в соседний Кыргызстан. Бихабибе 54 года, она замужем  и воспитывает 6 детей. Ее муж тоже работает, а по выходным помогает жене по бизнесу. Бихабиба планирует и дальше расширять свой бизнес, для чего собиратеся получить займ.
texts.en:
Bihabiba N. has been in business for over 15 years. From the very beginning she has bought and sold rice. To purchase the rice she travels to surrounding areas and to the wholesale market in neighboring Kyrgystan. Bihabiba is 54 years old, married, and is raising 6 children. Her husband also works, and help with the business on his days off. Bihabiba plans to continue to expand her business, which is why she is requesting a loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26 year old Bahati M. from Mwanza.  She is married with two children, between the ages of 1 and 4 years old. Bahati has been running a shop since 2006.
She works at the business for 13 hours per day, 6 days per week. Bahati currently earns about 120USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase cooking oil, sugar and kerosene.
In the future, she plans to expand her business. 
Bahati thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, sugar and kerosene

loans.name: Mahmudchon

texts.ru: Махмудчон неоднократно получал займ с Микроинвест и КИВА. Его бизнес развивается стабильно, его семья помогает ему. Сейчас наступает сезон весенней одежды и обуви и Махмудчон планирует закупить новый ассортимент. Для исполнения его планов ему необходимо 1200 сомони на 1 месяц. (на фото вы видите младшего сына Махмудчона)
texts.en:
Mahmudchon has taken out a loan from MicroInvest and Kiva several times. His business is developing steadily and his family helps him. Right now is the season of spring clothing and shoes and Mahmudchon plans to buy a new assortment. To realize his plans he needs 2000 somoni (US$350) for one month. (On the photo is the youngest son of Mahmudchon).

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sprint assortment of inventory

loans.name: Pablo Eugenio

texts.es: Su Nombre es Pablo Eugenio S. tiene 38 años de edad, su estado civil es casada, Don Pablo se dedica a la actividad económica es la venta de productos de veterinaria y servicios de asistencia. Hace más de 16 años que se dedica a este negocio pero es importante resaltar que este negocio surgió por la necesidad de enfrentar los gastos de su familia. Los propósitos de Don Pablo son de mantener su negocio y lograr más recursos para aumentar su inventario. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo ya que el desarrollo de su negocio ha sido por medio de los financiamientos y así poder ofertar a sus clientes la variedad de sus productos. Sus deseos son de obtener un lugar en donde estable ya que el ofrece estos productos de forma ambulante. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 9.000 córdobas.
texts.en:
Pablo Eugenio S. is 38 and married. Pablo sells veterinary products and services. He has had this business for more than 16 years, but it is important to note that the business arose out of the necessity to face his family’s expenses. Pablo’s intentions are to maintain his business and to gain more resources in order to augment his inventory. The loan that he is requesting is for working capital. The development of his business has been through loans and as such he has been able to offer his customers a variety of products. He wishes to obtain a permanent place, as he currently travels to sell his products. He is requesting C$9,000 córdobas.

Translated from Spanish by Deborah Delzell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.es:
En el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Ernestina M. se dedica con mucho esfuerzo a su negocio con el propósito de llevar a cabo la remodelación de su vivienda por la cual requiere de los materiales de construcción para así realizar su tarea y seguir adelante en el negocio.

Con gran esfuerzo ha logrado salir adelante y hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de los materiales ya que requiere mejorara sus condiciones y brindarle un techo digno a sus tres pequeños hijos. Con este crédito logrará continuar con la obra ya que iniciará con la puesta del techo de la vivienda y así continuará poco a poco hasta finalizar.
texts.en:
Hailing from Chinandega, Somotillo, Ernestina Martinez is a hard-working woman who is very interested in improving the lives of her children and the success of her business by remodeling the home out of which she runs her store. It is only with great effort that she has been able to get to where she currently is, and today she is coming to Ceprodel in search of a loan to cover the cost of the materials necessary to put a roof on her house, an improvement that she believes will push her business forward and finally allow her to offer a fitting home to her three young children.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 39 year old Jenifer M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children, between the ages of 3 and 23 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant because he is an orphan. Jenifer has been running a shop since 2007. Our client’s business is to sell women's cosmetics. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Jenifer currently earns about 120USD from her business. 
She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy more cosmetics and resell them to different customers. 
In the future, she plans to expand her business. 
Jenifer thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and resell them to different customers

loans.name: Kenia Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Kenia C. es una dama que se ha destacado por ser muy trabajadora dedicándose a su negocio de venta de cosméticos los cuales son vendidos por ella misma en su localidad en el mercado La Terminal de la ciudad de León.

Ella ha decidido mejorar su negocio y al habérsele agotado la mercadería ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para la compra de los cosméticos. Al habérsele brindado dicho crédito logrará mejorar su condición económica y saldrá adelante en la venta de los cosméticos.
texts.en:
Kenia C. is a woman who has distinguished herself through the hard work and dedication she has put into her cosmetic sales stand, which she runs in La Terminal market in the city of Leon. She has decided to improve her business by buying cosmetics in bulk, and is seeking the support of Ceprodel to cover the upfront costs. With this loan, she believes she will be able to further her business and improve her economic situation.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics

loans.name: Jafelina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26 year old Jafelina K. from Mwanza. She is single. Jafelina has been running a shop  since 2007. Our client’s business is to sell women’s cosmetics. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. 
Jafalina currently earns about 340USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy more cosmetics to resell them. 
In the future, she plans to expand her business. 
Jafelina thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and resell them

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Mariam M. from Mwanza. She is widowed with two children, between the ages of 3 and 6 years old. Mariam has been running a shop since 2006. Our client’s business is to sell different items such as soap, biscuits, water and ground nuts. She works at the business for 13 hours per day, 7 days per week. Mariam currently earns about 200USD from her business. 
She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy rice, cooking oil, sugar and wheat flour. 
In the future, she plans to open another business. 
Mariam thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To buy rice, cooking oil, sugar and wheat flour

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Juliana M. from Mwanza. She is widowed and has two children between the ages of 3 and 7. She has been running a charcoal business since 2008.

Charcoal is used by many Tanzanians as fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal), which they light with paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene.

Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative. Juliana works at the business 12 hours per day, six days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Juliana currently earns about $120 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more charcoal stock, as well as to increase her capital. In the future, she plans to open another business. Juliana thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets: thus, they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thereby enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal stock and to increase capital.

loans.name: Muzambil

texts.ru: Бизнес Музамбил продолжает развиваться. Получив свой первый займ с КИВА Музамбил довольно заметно развила свой бизнес. Ее муж (на фото) по прежнему продолжает помогать ей в ее торговле. Сейчас наступает сезон весенней одежды поэтому Музамбил решила подать заявку на очередной займ.
texts.en:
Muzambil's business keeps growing. When Muzambil received her first loan from Kiva she has noticeably developed her business. Her husband (on the photo) still helps her with her sales. Right now is the season for spring clothing and this is why Muzambil decided to apply for another loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a spring assortment of clothing

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Juliana K. from Mwanza. She is single and has one 23-year-old child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one other dependent because his parents do not take care of him.

Juliana has been running a nursery school since 1998. She is a wonderful woman who has devoted her career to the care and education of the Tanzanian young: she nurtures young Tanzanian boys and prepares them to enter elementary school. We could really use more dedicated people like her.

She works at the business eight hours per day, five days per week, and is assisted by 30 employees. Juliana currently earns about $150 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to build new classrooms. In the future, she plans to expand her school. Juliana thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets: thus, they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thereby enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To build new classrooms.

loans.name: Kawiya

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Kawia N. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 9 years old. Kawia has been running a shop business since 2005. Her business is to sell pens, pencils, body lotion, and cooking oil. She works at the business for 13 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Kawia currently earns about 100USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase rice, cooking oil, biscuits, and vouchers. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Kawia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice, cooking oil, biscuits, and vouchers.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.ru: Хабиба продолжает работать, а также одновременно к своей основной работе занимается бизнесом. Как и планировала Хабиба, она приобрела в аренду один из торговых мест в большом универмаге г. Исфары. Благодаря КИВА бизнес Хабибы приобрел устойчивость и подавая заявку на новый займ Хабиба собирается приобрести весенний ассортимент детской обуви.
texts.en:
Habiba continues working at her job and does her business at the same time. As Habiba has planned, she rented out a vendor stall in a large mall in the town of Isfara. Thanks to Kiva Habiba's business has stabilized and now Habiba is applying for a new loan and plans to purchase a spring assortment of children's shoes.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a spring assortment of children's shoes

loans.name: Celina Alejandra

texts.es: Celina Alejandra C. D. G., resiD. en el cantón el Carmen en Zacatecoluca. A sus 42 años D. edad trabaja arduamente para proveer D. todas las necesidades básicas a su familia, ya que ella tiene 4 hijos cuyas edades oscilan desD. los 11 años hasta los 19 años D. edad, todos son estudiantes. Es por esto que Celina día con día trabaja en su propio negocio el cuál esta ubicado en el Instituto Nacional del Rosario D. La Paz, ahí ella venD. pupusas (comida típica salvadoreña), golosinas, bebidas  como sodas, café, entre otros productos, todo esto lo comercializa a los estudiantes D. dicho instituto. Celina solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda incrementar los productos D. su negocio, D. manera que logre vender más y obtener mayores ingresos, los cuales le permita dar alimentación, vestido y estudio a sus cuatro hijos, los cuales son el motor que impulsa a Celina a esforzarse cada día.
texts.en:
Celina Alejandra C. D. G. lives in Carmen, Zacatecoluca. At 42 years old, she struggles to proviD. basic necessities to her 4 children, ranging from 11-19 years of age, all of whom are in school. That is the reason that Celina works day in and day out at her food stand, where she sells popusas (a traditional Salvadoran food), candy, sodas, coffee, as well as other products, to the students of Instituto Nacional Del Rosario D. La Paz, the school near which her store is located. Celina is asking for a loan which she will use to improve the selection that she can offer in order to attract customers and improve her income, which in turn will allow her to proviD. food, clothing, and schooling to the 4 beautiful children who are her reason for getting out of bed every day.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of more products for her store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Mary S. from Mwanza. She is married with two children between the ages of 1 and 9 years old. Mary S. has been running a beauty salon since 1999. Her business is Beauty Salon, a place where you can buy hair extensions in different styles--long, short, curly, straight, red, blue--and have it woven, cut, or braided. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Mary currently earns about 200USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase weaving tools, long hair extensions, clothes, and shoes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mary thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase weaving tools, long hair extensions, clothes, and shoes.

loans.name: Edelmira

texts.es: Edelmira R. V., reside en Ahuachapán, a sus 57 años de edad vive únicamente con su esposo, el cuál junto a ella gozan de una excelente reputación como personas muy trabajadoras y responsables. Edelmira posee un negocio en el cuál se encarga de vender productos de primera necesidad tales como arroz, frijoles, aceites, jugos, etcétera. Así mismo vende en el mismo lugar productos hecho de barro como alcancías, cómales, cabe mencionar que cómales es un producto el cuál se realiza para cocinar las tortillas y es como una cacerola plana hecha de barro. Dicho negocio lo posee desde hace 29 años atrás. Edelmira desea obtener un préstamo a través del cuál pueda invertir mucho más en su negocio e incluir más productos elaborados con barro y productos de primera necesidad.  De esta manera espera poder aumentar sus ventas para poder mejorar la economía familiar.
texts.en:
Edelmira R. V., 57, lives in Ahuachapán with her husband, who along with her, enjoys an excellent reputation as a responsible and hardworking person. Edmelmira runs a business which sells staples such as rice, beans, oil, juice, etc, in addition to goods made of clay such as bowls or earthenware for the preparation of tortillas. She has run this business for 29 years, and is in search of a loan which she can use to invest in her business and provide greater variety in the goods that she already sells. This way she hopes to increase her sales and improve her family's economic situation.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Esther M. from Mwanza. She is married with five children between the ages of 12 and 19 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Esther has been running a tailoring business since 2006. Her business is to make clothes and sell them to customers. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Esther currently earns about 250USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy thread, a sewing machine and kangas. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Esther thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy thread, a sewing machine, and kangas

loans.name: Félix Alexander Mejía

texts.es: Félix Alexander M. de 39 años de edad reside en Cojutepeque, junto a su compañera de vida, trabajan muy duro día con día, él posee una venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado del lugar, Félix desea aumentar las ventas de su negocio ya que esta es la única fuente de ingresos que posee junto a su esposa. Es por ello que él solicita un préstamo a través del cuál pueda comprar más verduras y frutas y de esta manera poder solventar algunas deudas y aumentar los productos de su negocio. Félix goza de muy buena reputación en su lugar de trabajo y vivienda ya que se destaca por ser muy responsable y amable, y su único deseo es poder mejorar su estilo de vida obteniendo más ingresos a través de su negocio.
texts.en:
Felix Alexander Mejia, 39 years old, lives in Cojutepeque with his life partner. They both work very hard day in and day out. He has a fruit and vegetable stand in the local market. Felix wants to increase the sales of his business, since this is the only source of income that he and his wife have. This is the reason for his loan request, with which he will be able to buy more vegetables and fruit and thus be able to pay off some of his debt and increase the merchandise for his business. Felix has a very good reputation where he works and lives, he goes out of his way to be responsible and kind. His only wish is to be able to improve his lifestyle by increasing the income from his business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more fruits and vegetables for the business.

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Lilian Escolástica

texts.es: Lilian Escolástica A. D. A. resiD. en Tamalique, vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como mecánico y un hijo D. 19 años D. edad el cuál estudia bachillerato. Ella posee un pequeño negocio D. venta D. ropa, zapatos y prendas D. oro para mujer. Se destaca por ser una mujer muy trabajadora la cuál se esfuerza por contribuir junto a su esposo en todo lo necesario para su hogar. Es por esto que Lilian desea obtener un préstamo a través del cual pueda incrementar la mercadería D. su negocio D. manera que logre ofrecer más variedad a sus clientes y así mismo obtener nuevos clientes, D. manera que pueda obtener mayores ganancias a través D. las cuales contribuya junto a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y también poder brindarle estudios superiores a su hijo.
texts.en:
Lilian Escolástica A. D. A. resides in Tamalique. She lives with her husband who works as a mechanic and her 19 year old son who is studying for his university entrance exams. She owns a small business selling clothing, shoes and gold jewelery for women. She is a hardworking woman who, alongsiD. her husband, strives to proviD. everything her home needs. As such, she wishes to get a loan so that she can expand the merchandise available at her shop and offer more variety to her customers. This will help her attract new customers and earn greater profits, enabling her to contribute to the household expenses with her husband and proviD. her son access to higher education.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Nicoll, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of more merchandise for her business

loans.name: Angel

texts.es:
Ángel F. L. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de tembladerani, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz junto a su esposa, la señora Sandra Terán.
Ángel es empleado de la administración pública en esta ciudad y su esposa se dedica a las labores del hogar.
El crédito solicitado será para la construcción de una cocina en su vivienda, la misma que se encuentra solo en la fase de construcción de muros  y techo.
Esta es la segunda vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Ángel F. L. lives in his own home, in the Tembladerani neighborhood on the western side of the city of La Paz along with his wife, Mrs. Sandra Terán. Ángel is employed as a public administrator in the city and his wife is a homemaker. This loan will be used to build a kitchen in his home, which is currently in the beginning stages of construction and has only walls and a roof. This is the second time that he has requested a loan, and his credit report qualifies him to take out another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Fransisca Del Socorro

texts.es: Francisca del Socorro R. R. tiene la edad de 52 años, su estado civil es soltera. Tiene 3 hijos y todos trabajan de forma independiente. La actividad económica de Doña Francisca es la venta de mercadería en general como ropa, calzado y cosmético. Hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio cada uno de los financiamientos han sido provechosos por lo que todos han sido destinado para capital de trabajo. Los deseos de Doña Francisca son de ahorra los ingresos del negocio y poder ahorrar para poder soportar la situación económica en un futuro. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 5.500 córdobas.
texts.en:
Francisca del Socorro R. R. is 52 years old and single. She has 3 children who all work on their own. The main occupation of Ms. Francisca is the sale of general merchandise such as clothing, shoes and cosmetics. She has been in this business for 7 years. Each one of her loans has been productive for they all went to increase her working capital. Ms. Francisca wishes to be able to save the income from the business to be able to provide for her financial support in the future. She is requesting a loan of C$ 5500 cordobas.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Rose Mango from Mwanza. She is single and has two children between the ages of 12 and 19. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because he is an orphan.

Rose has been running a pig and poultry business since 2004. The pig and poultry business is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially among SELFINA clients. Nguruwe means pig in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. They can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide protein.

Rose works at her business for 12 hours per day, seven days per week, and is assisted by one employee. She currently earns about $150 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy more pigs. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Rose thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets: thus, they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thereby enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more pigs.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesús

texts.es: Manuel de Jesús L., de 51 años de edad, reside en Cojutepeque, vive junto a su hijo de 18 años, estudiante de tercer años de bachillerato y su hija de 17 años de edad la cuál estudia segundo año de bachillerato. Manuel tiene más de ocho años de poseer un despacho contable y también tiene una tienda en la cuál vende productos de primera necesidad. El de deseo de Manuel es poder obtener un préstamo a través del cual pueda aumentar los productos de su negocio y así mismo comprar papelería para su despacho. Manuel desea mejorar sus ingresos a través de sus negocios ya que son estos lo que le permiten brindarles todo lo necesario a sus hijos como lo es la alimentación, vestuario, hogar y estudios. Manuel goza de una excelente reputación en su lugar de vivienda, ya que se esfuerza a diario por sus hijos, para brindarle un mejor estilo de vida y un mejor futuro para ellos.
texts.en:
Manuel de Jesús L., 51 years old, lives in Cojutepeque with his 17 year old daughter and 18 year old son who are in their second and third years of high school, respectively. For eight years Manuel has owned an accounting office and also owns a shop that sells basic necessities. Manuel wants to take out a loan with which he can buy office supplies and more products for his shop. He wants to increase the income he receives from his businesses because they allow him to provide his children everything they need such as food, clothing, housing and education. Manuel has an excellent reputation where he lives as he works daily for his children to provide them with a better quality of life and a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Nicoll, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more material for his business

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz A. Velásquez vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Las Lomas, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo,  y sus dos  hijos.
Beatriz es empleada en una lavandería y su esposo realiza empanadas que vende a las tiendas de barrio.
El crédito es para la refacción del ambiente que usan para la elaboración de masitas, y así lograr una mejor producción.
Esta es la primera vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Beatriz A. Velásquez lives in her own house in the zone of Las Lomas, on the west side of La Paz, with her husband and her two children. Beatriz works in a laundromat and her husband makes empanadas which he sells to neighborhood shops. Her loan will go towards refurbishing of area they use to prepare the dough, enabling them to achieve greater production. This is the first loan request from Beatriz and their socioeconomic analysis shows she and her husband to be favorably qualified to have access to credit.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Nicoll, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36 year old Nana K. from Mwanza. She is married with three children, between the ages of 14 and 18 years old. Nana has been running a shop since 2007. Our client’s business is to sell common items from her shop such as wheat flour, salt, biscuits and cooking oil. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Nana currently earns about 120USD from her business. 
She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase salts, wheat flour, biscuits and cooking oil. In the future, she plans to expand her business. 
Nana thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase salts, wheat flour, biscuits and cooking oil

loans.name: Anitha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 37 year old Anitha S. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, between the ages of 5 and 9 years old. Anitha has been running a poultry business since 2002. Our client’s business is Poultry/kuku business. 
Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. 
She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by two employees. Anitha currently earns about 360USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy chicks and continue with poultry business. 
In the future, she plans to expand her poultry business. 
Anitha thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy chicks and continue with poultry business

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
Miguel G. F. vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de Irpavi, zona sur-este de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposa y sus dos hijos.
Miguel trabaja como empleado en un café de esta ciudad. 
El crédito solicitado será para la refacción de su vivienda, ya que por el paso del tiempo sufrió deterioro de los techos y los muros interiores.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Miguel G. F. lives with his wife and two children in his parents' house in Irpavi, a south-eastern zone of the city of La Paz. Miguel works in La Paz at a café. The requested loan with go towards carrying out renovations to the roof and interior walls of his parents' house which have deteriorated over time. This is the fourth time he has requested a loan and, according to his socioeconomic analysis, is well qualified to access a line of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Nicoll, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Lesbia De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La señora Lesbia S. es una dama que con mucho esfuerzo dedica su tiempo a su negocio de venta de alimentos los cuales son preparados por ella misma todos los días para ofrecerlos en su comidería en el municipio de Ciudad Sandino de la ciudad de Managua.

Ella se ha destacado por ser una persona muy trabajadora que ha logrado salir adelante y para ello ha hecho uso de los créditos brindados por Ceprodel. Hoy en día la razón por la que ha solicitado un crédito es para la compra de la materia prima ya que requiere obtener los materiales para hacer los alimentos y así continuar en su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lesbia S. is a woman who, with great effort, dedicates her time to her business, where she sells foods that she prepares herself every day in order to provide them in her eatery in the municipality of Ciudad Sandino in the city of Managua. She has stood out as a very hard-working person who has managed to get ahead and for this she has made use of the loans provided by Ceprodel. The reason that she has requested a loan now is to purchase raw materials, as she needs to get the ingredients to make the foods and in this way to move forward with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Yuster

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Yuster M. from Mwanza. She is married and has three children between the ages of 15 and 24. She is also responsible for supporting two additional dependents because their parents do not take care of them.

Yuster has been running a clothes business since 2008. Her store sells kanga and vitenge, which are traditional kinds of clothing worn by Tanzanian women. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile: the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.
